dublinCore.dc:title: 119 S1501 IS: Safe American Food Exports Act of 2025
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Wicker (for himself, Ms. Smith, Mrs. Britt, and Mr. Coons) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry

form.official-title: To amend the Animal Health Protection Act to improve the prevention of the spread of animal diseases, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Safe American Food Exports Act of 2025 or the SAFE Act of 2025.

subsection.text: Section 10405 of the Animal Health Protection Act (7 U.S.C. 8304) is amended—

paragraph.text: by redesignating subsection (d) as subsection (e); and
by inserting after subsection (c) the following:

To reduce the impact of animal disease outbreaks on United States exports, the Secretary, acting through the Administrator of the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, the Under Secretary of Agriculture for Trade and Foreign Agricultural Affairs, and the Administrator of the Food Safety and Inspection Service, in consultation with the United States Trade Representative, may negotiate regionalization, zoning, compartmentalization, and other agreements regarding outbreaks of known animal disease threats of trade significance with the governments of countries with export markets for livestock animals or animal products from the United States.
A negotiation carried out under paragraph (1) should take into account accepted global research advances.
limits the ability of the United States Trade Representative to negotiate trade agreements; or

requires the United States Trade Representative to condition other trade agreements on the inclusion of language relating to reducing the impact of animal disease outbreaks on United States exports, as described in subsection (d)(1) of section 10405 of the Animal Health Protection Act (7 U.S.C. 8304).
